abate: to decrease in force or intensity
abdicate: to renounce a throne, high office, dignity, or function
aberrant:1: deviating from the usual or natural type : atypical, abnormal
abhorrent: causing or deserving strong dislike or hatred : being so repugnant as to stir up positive antagonism
abstain: to choose not to do or have something : to refrain and often with an effort of self-denial from an action or practice
abstemious: marked by restraint especially in the eating of food or drinking of alcohol; also : reflecting such restraint
abysmal: immeasurably low or wretched : extremely poor or bad
abyss: an immeasurably deep gulf or great space
accession:1: the act or process by which someone rises to a position of honor or power
acidulous: somewhat acid or harsh in taste or manner
acquiesced: to accept, comply, or submit tacitly or passively —often used with in or to
acrimonious: angry and bitter : caustic, biting, or rancorous especially in feeling, language, or manner
ad hoc:1: for the particular end or case at hand without consideration of wider application
ad hominem:1: appealing to feelings or prejudices rather than intellect
ad nauseam: to a sickening or excessive degree
adduce: to offer as example, reason, or proof in discussion or analysis
admonish: to express warning or disapproval to especially in a gentle, earnest, or solicitous manner
adorn: to enhance the appearance of especially with beautiful objects
adroit: having or showing skill, cleverness, or resourcefulness in handling situations
aegis: a shield or breastplate emblematic of majesty that was associated with Zeus and Athena
affable: being pleasant and at ease in talking to others
affectation: speech or conduct not natural to oneself : an unnatural form of behavior meant especially to impress others
affliction: a cause of persistent pain or distress
aggrandize: to make great or greater : increase, enlarge
aghast: struck with terror, amazement, or horror : shocked and upset
agog:1: full of intense interest or excitement : eager
agrarian:1: of or relating to fields or lands or their tenure
ailment: a bodily disorder or chronic disease
allure:1: to entice by charm or attraction
aloof:1: removed or distant either physically or emotionally
altruistic: relating to or given to altruism:
ambivalent: having or showing simultaneous and contradictory attitudes or feelings toward something or someone : characterized by ambivalence
ameliorate: to make better or more tolerable
androgynous: having the characteristics or nature of both male and female
anecdote: a usually short narrative of an interesting, amusing, or biographical incident
animus: a usually prejudiced and often spiteful or malevolent ill will
annul: to declare or make legally invalid or void
anomaly: something different, abnormal, peculiar, or not easily classified : something anomalous
antediluvian: of or relating to the period before the flood described in the Bible
antic:1: an attention-drawing, often wildly playful or funny act or action : caper —usually plural
apathetic: affected by, characterized by, or displaying apathy : having or showing little or no interest, concern, or emotion
apathy: lack of feeling or emotion : impassiveness
aphorism: a concise statement of a principle
apogee: the point in the orbit of an object (such as a satellite) orbiting the earth that is at the greatest distance from the center of the earth; also : the point farthest from a planet or a satellite (such as the moon) reached by an object orbiting it
apotheosis: the perfect form or example of something : quintessence
arbiter: a person with power to decide a dispute : judge
arbitrage:1: the nearly simultaneous purchase and sale of securities or foreign exchange in different markets in order to profit from price discrepancies
arbitrary: existing or coming about seemingly at random or by chance or as a capricious and unreasonable act of will
ardent: characterized by warmth of feeling typically expressed in eager zealous support or activity
artless: lacking art, knowledge, or skill : uncultured
ascertain: to find out or learn with certainty
asinine: extremely or utterly foolish or silly
assuage: to lessen the intensity of (something that pains or distresses) : ease
asymptote: a straight line associated with a curve such that as a point moves along an infinite branch of the curve the distance from the point to the line approaches zero and the slope of the curve at the point approaches the slope of the line
atavism: recurrence in an organism of a trait or character typical of an ancestral form and usually due to genetic recombination
atrophy:1: decrease in size or wasting away of a body part or tissue; also : arrested development or loss of a part or organ incidental to the normal development or life of an animal or plant
attenuate:1: to lessen the amount, force, magnitude, or value of : weaken
august: marked by majestic dignity or grandeur
austere: stern and cold in appearance or manner
avail:1: to be of use or advantage : serve
available: present or ready for immediate use
banal: lacking originality, freshness, or novelty : trite
banter:1: to speak to or address in a witty and teasing manner
barrage:1: a dam placed in a watercourse to increase the depth of water or to divert it into a channel for navigation or irrigation
beget: to procreate as the father : sire
behoove: to be necessary, proper, or advantageous for
bellicose: favoring or inclined to start quarrels or wars
bemoan: to express deep grief or distress over
bequest: the act of giving or leaving something by will : the act of bequeathing
bereft: deprived or robbed of the possession or use of something —usually used with of
beseech: to beg for urgently or anxiously
besmirch: to cause harm or damage to the purity, luster, or beauty of (something) : sully, soil
bewitched: controlled or affected by or as if by a magic spell : influenced, attracted, or charmed as if by magic
blase: apathetic to pleasure or excitement as a result of excessive indulgence or enjoyment : world-weary
blight:1: a disease or injury of plants marked by the formation of lesions, withering, and death of parts (such as leaves and tubers)
blithe: lacking due thought or consideration : casual, heedless
blowhard: an arrogantly and pompously boastful or opinionated person : braggart, windbag
bombastic: marked by or given to speech or writing that is given exaggerated importance by artificial or empty means : marked by or given to bombast : pompous, overblown
boycott: to engage in a concerted refusal to have dealings with (a person, a store, an organization, etc.) usually to express disapproval or to force acceptance of certain conditions
breadth: distance from side to side : width
brevity: shortness of duration; especially : shortness or conciseness of expression
burgeon: to send forth new growth (such as buds or branches) : sprout
Byzantine:1: of, relating to, or characteristic of the ancient city of Byzantium
cachet: a seal used especially as a mark of official approval
cacophony: harsh or jarring sound : dissonance; specifically : harshness in the sound of words or phrases
calumniate: to utter maliciously false statements, charges, or imputations about
capacious: containing or capable of containing a great deal
capricious: governed or characterized by caprice : impulsive, unpredictable
castigate: to subject to severe punishment, reproof, or criticism
catatonia: a psychomotor disturbance that may involve muscle rigidity, stupor or mutism, purposeless movements, negativism, echolalia, and inappropriate or unusual posturing and is associated with various medical conditions (such as schizophrenia and mood disorders)
catatonic: of, relating to, marked by, or affected with catatonia
categorical imperative: a moral obligation or command that is unconditionally and universally binding
cathartic:1: of, relating to, or producing catharsis
cauterize: to sear with a cautery or caustic
caveat: a warning enjoining one from certain acts or practices
chronic: continuing or occurring again and again for a long time
clairvoyance: the power or faculty of discerning objects not present to the senses
clandestine: marked by, held in, or conducted with secrecy : surreptitious
clout:1: a piece of cloth or leather : rag
coda: a concluding musical section that is formally distinct from the main structure
coercion: the act, process, or power of coercing
cogency: the quality or state of being cogent
cognizant: knowledgeable of something especially through personal experience; also : mindful
coitus: physical union of male and female genitalia accompanied by rhythmic movements : sexual intercourse
coitus interruptus: coitus in which the penis is withdrawn prior to ejaculation to prevent the deposit of sperm into the vagina
colloquium: a usually academic meeting at which specialists deliver addresses on a topic or on related topics and then answer questions relating to them
collusion: secret agreement or cooperation especially for an illegal or deceitful purpose
commensurate: corresponding in size, extent, amount, or degree : proportionate
compendium: a brief summary of a larger work or of a field of knowledge : abstract
complicity: association or participation in or as if in a wrongful act
concession: the act or an instance of conceding (as by granting something as a right, accepting something as true, or acknowledging defeat)
concomitant:1: accompanying especially in a subordinate or incidental way
conduit: a natural or artificial channel through which something (such as a fluid) is conveyed
confer: to compare views or take counsel : consult
confound: to throw (a person) into confusion or perplexity
congenital: existing at or dating from birth
console:1: an architectural member projecting from a wall to form a bracket or from a keystone for ornament
conspicuous: obvious to the eye or mind
consternation: amazement or dismay that hinders or throws into confusion
contentious: likely to cause disagreement or argument
contrite: feeling or showing sorrow and remorse for a sin or shortcoming
contrition: the state of being contrite : repentance
convalesce: to recover health and strength gradually after sickness or weakness
conviction: the act or process of finding a person guilty of a crime especially in a court of law
convivial: relating to, occupied with, or fond of feasting, drinking, and good company
cornucopia: a curved, hollow goat's horn or similarly shaped receptacle (such as a horn-shaped basket) that is overflowing especially with fruit and vegetables (such as gourds, ears of corn, apples, and grapes) and that is used as a decorative motif emblematic of abundance —called also horn of plenty
corral:1: a pen or enclosure for confining or capturing livestock
corrigible: capable of being set right : reparable
crass: gross; especially : having or indicating such grossness of mind as precludes delicacy and discrimination
credulous: ready to believe especially on slight or uncertain evidence
crepuscular: of, relating to, or resembling twilight : dim
cronyism: partiality to cronies especially as evidenced in the appointment of political hangers-on to office without regard to their qualifications
cursory: rapidly and often superficially performed or produced : hasty
cynical: having or showing the attitude or temper of a cynic: such as
debilitate: to impair the strength of : enfeeble
decrepit: wasted and weakened by or as if by the infirmities of old age
deign: to condescend reluctantly and with a strong sense of the affront to one's superiority that is involved : stoop
deliberate:1: to think about or discuss issues and decisions carefully
delineate: to describe, portray, or set forth with accuracy or in detail
deluge:1: an overflowing of the land by water
demagogue:1: a leader who makes use of popular prejudices and false claims and promises in order to gain power
denounce: to pronounce especially publicly to be blameworthy or evil
desperation: loss of hope and surrender to despair
diaspora: the Jews living outside Palestine or modern Israel
diatribe: a bitter and abusive speech or piece of writing
dichotomy: a division into two especially mutually exclusive or contradictory groups or entities; also : the process or practice of making such a division
dilettante: a person having a superficial interest in an art or a branch of knowledge : dabbler
diminutive:1: a word, affix, or name usually indicating small size : a diminutive word, affix, or name
disenfranchise: to deprive of a franchise, of a legal right, or of some privilege or immunity; especially : to deprive of the right to vote
disenfranchised: deprived of some right, privilege, or immunity; especially : deprived of the right to vote
disingenuous: lacking in candor; also : giving a false appearance of simple frankness : calculating
dismay:1: to cause to lose courage or resolution (as because of alarm or fear)
doff: to remove (an article of wear) from the body
dote: to exhibit mental decline of or like that of old age : be in one's dotage
double entendre: a word or expression capable of two interpretations with one usually risqué
draconian: of, relating to, or characteristic of Draco or the severe code of laws held to have been framed by him
dross: the scum or unwanted material that forms on the surface of molten metal
ebb:1: the reflux of the tide toward the sea
effusive: marked by the expression of great or excessive emotion or enthusiasm
egalitarian: asserting, promoting, or marked by egalitarianism
elucidate: to make lucid especially by explanation or analysis
emphatic: uttered with or marked by emphasis
encomium: glowing and warmly enthusiastic praise; also : an expression of this
encroach: to enter by gradual steps or by stealth into the possessions or rights of another
endemic:1: belonging or native to a particular people or country
endow: to furnish with an income; especially : to make a grant of money providing for the continuing support or maintenance of
engross: to copy or write in a large hand
epitaph: an inscription on or at a tomb or a grave in memory of the one buried there
epithet: a characterizing word or phrase accompanying or occurring in place of the name of a person or thing
epitome: a typical or ideal example : embodiment
erudite: having or showing knowledge that is gained by studying : possessing or displaying erudition
esoteric: designed for or understood by the specially initiated alone
estrange: to arouse especially mutual enmity or indifference in (someone) where there had formerly been love, affection, or friendliness : alienate
ethos: the distinguishing character, sentiment, moral nature, or guiding beliefs of a person, group, or institution; also : ethic
eunuch: a castrated man placed in charge of a harem or employed as a chamberlain in a palace
euphemism: the substitution of an agreeable or inoffensive expression for one that may offend or suggest something unpleasant; also : the expression so substituted
exacerbate: to make more violent, bitter, or severe
exaltation: an act of exalting : the state of being exalted
exonerate: to relieve of a responsibility, obligation, or hardship
extricate: to free or remove from an entanglement or difficulty
exuberance: the quality or state of being exuberant
facetious: joking or jesting often inappropriately : waggish
faction: a party or group (as within a government) that is often contentious or self-seeking : clique
faux pas: a significant or embarrassing error or mistake : blunder; especially : a socially awkward or improper act or remark
forage:1: food for animals especially when taken by browsing or grazing
forebode: to have an inward conviction of (something, such as a coming ill or misfortune)
foresight: an act or the power of foreseeing : prescience
formative:1: giving or capable of giving form : constructive
fraught:1: full of or accompanied by something specified —used with with
fringe:1: an ornamental border consisting of short straight or twisted threads or strips hanging from cut or raveled edges or from a separate band
frivolity: the quality or state of being frivolous
frugal: characterized by or reflecting economy in the use of resources
garrulous: given to prosy, rambling, or tedious loquacity : pointlessly or annoyingly talkative
glib: showing little forethought or preparation : offhand
gossamer:1: a film of cobwebs floating in air in calm clear weather
gratitude: the state of being grateful : thankfulness
gregarious: tending to associate with others of one's kind : social
grovel: to creep with the face to the ground : crawl
haphazard:1: marked by lack of plan, order, or direction
harangue:1: a speech addressed to a public assembly
harbinger:1: something that foreshadows a future event : something that gives an anticipatory sign of what is to come
heretic: a person who differs in opinion from established religious dogma; especially : a baptized member of the Roman Catholic Church who refuses to acknowledge or accept a revealed truth
hermetic: of or relating to the mystical and alchemical writings or teachings arising in the first three centuries a.d. and attributed to Hermes Trismegistus
heuristic:1: involving or serving as an aid to learning, discovery, or problem-solving by experimental and especially trial-and-error methods; also : of or relating to exploratory problem-solving techniques that utilize self-educating techniques (such as the evaluation of feedback) to improve performance
hindsight: perception of the nature of an event after it has happened
idiosyncrasy: a peculiarity of constitution or temperament : an individualizing characteristic or quality
impasse: a predicament affording no obvious escape
impetuous: marked by impulsive vehemence or passion
implicate: to bring into intimate or incriminating connection
impregnate:1: to cause to be filled, imbued, permeated, or saturated
incarnate:1: invested with bodily and especially human nature and form
incessant: continuing or following without interruption : unceasing
inchoate: being only partly in existence or operation : incipient; especially : imperfectly formed or formulated : formless, incoherent
incipient: beginning to come into being or to become apparent
incisive: impressively direct and decisive (as in manner or presentation)
incorrigible: incapable of being corrected or amended: such as
incredulous: unwilling to admit or accept what is offered as true : not credulous : skeptical
indelible: that cannot be removed, washed away, or erased
indict: to charge with a crime by the finding or presentment of a jury (such as a grand jury) in due form of law
indignant: feeling or showing anger because of something unjust or unworthy : filled with or marked by indignation
indignation: anger aroused by something unjust, unworthy, or mean
inexorable: not to be persuaded, moved, or stopped : relentless
inexplicable: incapable of being explained, interpreted, or accounted for
inhibition: an inner impediment to free activity, expression, or functioning: such as
inhospitable: not showing hospitality : not friendly or receptive
insensible: incapable or bereft of feeling or sensation: such as
insipid: lacking in qualities that interest, stimulate, or challenge : dull, flat
insolence: the quality or state of being insolent
insolent: insultingly contemptuous in speech or conduct : overbearing
insular: characteristic of an isolated people; especially : being, having, or reflecting a narrow provincial viewpoint
interlude: an intervening or interruptive period, space, or event : interval
interstitial: occurring in or being an interval or intervening space or segment : of, relating to, or forming an interstice
intractable: not easily governed, managed, or directed
investiture: the act of establishing in office or ratifying
irretrievable: not retrievable : impossible to regain or recover
juncture: a point of time; especially : one made critical by a concurrence of circumstances
kerfuffle: a disturbance or commotion typically caused by a dispute or conflict
kludge: a haphazard or makeshift solution to a problem and especially to a computer or programming problem
lackadaisical: lacking life, spirit, or zest : languid
lash:1: to move violently or suddenly : dash
latent:1: present and capable of emerging or developing but not now visible, obvious, active, or symptomatic
litany: a prayer consisting of a series of invocations and supplications by the leader with alternate responses by the congregation
lofty: elevated in character and spirit : noble
Luddite: one of a group of early 19th century English workmen destroying laborsaving machinery as a protest; broadly : one who is opposed to especially technological change
macabre: having death as a subject : comprising or including a personalized representation of death
malfeasance: wrongdoing or misconduct especially by a public official
masquerade:1: a social gathering of persons wearing masks and often fantastic costumes
mercurial:1: of, relating to, or born under the planet Mercury
microcosm: a little world; especially : the human race or human nature seen as an epitome of the world or the universe
middling:1: of middle, medium, or moderate size, degree, or quality
milieu: the physical or social setting in which something occurs or develops : environment
millenarian:1: of or relating to belief in a millennium
mire:1: wet spongy earth (as of a bog or marsh)
mirth: gladness or gaiety as shown by or accompanied with laughter
misnomer: the misnaming of a person in a legal instrument
modicum: a small portion : a limited quantity
moratorium: a legally authorized period of delay in the performance of a legal obligation or the payment of a debt
mot juste: the exactly right word or phrasing
myopia: a condition in which the visual images come to a focus in front of the retina of the eye resulting especially in defective vision of distant objects : nearsightedness
nascent: coming or having recently come into existence
nebulous: of, relating to, or resembling a nebula : nebular
non sequitur: an inference that does not follow from the premises; specifically : a fallacy resulting from a simple conversion of a universal affirmative proposition or from the transposition of a condition and its consequent
nondescript: belonging or appearing to belong to no particular class or kind : not easily described
normative: of, relating to, or determining norms or standards
oblivion: the fact or condition of not remembering : a state marked by lack of awareness or consciousness
obsequious: marked by or exhibiting a fawning attentiveness
obstinacy: the quality or state of being obstinate : stubbornness
opulent: exhibiting or characterized by opulence: such as
ostentation: excessive display : vain and unnecessary show especially for the purpose of attracting attention, admiration, or envy : pretentiousness
outlandish: of or relating to another country : foreign
panacea: a remedy for all ills or difficulties : cure-all
panache: an ornamental tuft (as of feathers) especially on a helmet
paradigm: example, pattern; especially : an outstandingly clear or typical example or archetype
pariah: a member of a low caste of southern India
parochial: of or relating to a church parish
paroxysm: a fit, attack, or sudden increase or recurrence of symptoms (as of a disease) : convulsion
parthenogenesis: reproduction by development of an unfertilized usually female gamete that occurs especially among lower plants and invertebrate animals
pastime: something that amuses and serves to make time pass agreeably : diversion
patina: a usually green film formed naturally on copper and bronze by long exposure or artificially (as by acids) and often valued aesthetically for its color
pedantic: of, relating to, or being a pedant
pejorative:1: a word or phrase that has negative connotations or that is intended to disparage or belittle : a pejorative word or phrase
peonage: the use of laborers bound in servitude because of debt
perfidious: of, relating to, or characterized by perfidy
perfunctory: characterized by routine or superficiality : mechanical
perplex: to make unable to grasp something clearly or to think logically and decisively about something
pestilential: causing or tending to cause pestilence : deadly
petrify: to convert (organic matter) into stone or a substance of stony hardness by the infiltration of water and the deposition of dissolved mineral matter
phalanx: a body of heavily armed infantry in ancient Greece formed in close deep ranks and files; broadly : a body of troops in close array
pious: marked by or showing reverence for deity and devotion to divine worship
pithy: consisting of or abounding in pith
placate: to soothe or mollify especially by concessions : appease
platitude: the quality or state of being dull or insipid
plausible: superficially fair, reasonable, or valuable but often specious
polemic: an aggressive attack on or refutation of the opinions or principles of another
pontificate:1: to speak or express opinions in a pompous or dogmatic way
posterity: the offspring of one progenitor to the furthest generation
preamble: an introductory statement; especially : the introductory part of a constitution or statute that usually states the reasons for and intent of the law
precarious: dependent on chance circumstances, unknown conditions, or uncertain developments
precipice: a very steep or overhanging place
preclude: to make impossible by necessary consequence : rule out in advance
precocious: exceptionally early in development or occurrence
predation: the killing by one living organism of another for food : a mode of life in which food is primarily obtained by the killing and consuming of animals
preoccupied: previously applied to another group and unavailable for use in a new sense —used of a biological generic or specific name
prerogative: an exclusive or special right, power, or privilege: such as
presentiment: a feeling that something will or is about to happen : premonition
presume: to undertake without leave or clear justification : dare
pretense: a claim made or implied; especially : one not supported by fact
prevail: to gain ascendancy through strength or superiority : triumph
privation: an act or instance of depriving : deprivation
probative: serving to test or try : exploratory
proclivity: an inclination or predisposition toward something; especially : a strong inherent inclination toward something objectionable
propensity: an often intense natural inclination or preference
prophylactic:1: guarding from or preventing the spread or occurrence of disease or infection
proselytize: to induce someone to convert to one's faith
provisional:1: serving for the time being : temporary
proximity: the quality or state of being proximate : closeness
proxy: the agency, function, or office of a deputy who acts as a substitute for another
prudent: characterized by, arising from, or showing prudence: such as
prurient: marked by or arousing an immoderate or unwholesome interest or desire; especially : marked by, arousing, or appealing to sexual desire
quaint: pleasingly or strikingly old-fashioned or unfamiliar
quandary: a state of perplexity or doubt
quell:1: to thoroughly overwhelm and reduce to submission or passivity
quixotic: foolishly impractical especially in the pursuit of ideals; especially : marked by rash lofty romantic ideas or extravagantly chivalrous action
recalcitrant: obstinately defiant of authority or restraint
recidivism: a tendency to relapse into a previous condition or mode of behavior; especially : relapse into criminal behavior
recompense:1: to give something to by way of compensation (as for a service rendered or damage incurred)
recuse: to disqualify (oneself) as judge in a particular case; broadly : to remove (oneself) from participation to avoid a conflict of interest
remiss: negligent in the performance of work or duty : careless
reproach:1: an expression of rebuke or disapproval
repudiation: the act of repudiating : the state of being repudiated; especially : the refusal of public authorities to acknowledge or pay a debt
resolve:1: to deal with successfully : clear up
rhetoric: the art of speaking or writing effectively: such as
ruminate: to go over in the mind repeatedly and often casually or slowly
sabbatical:1: of or relating to a sabbatical year
salacious: arousing or appealing to sexual desire or imagination
schadenfreude: enjoyment obtained from the troubles of others
scrupulous: having moral integrity : acting in strict regard for what is considered right or proper
sedition: incitement of resistance to or insurrection against lawful authority
self-righteous: convinced of one's own righteousness especially in contrast with the actions and beliefs of others : narrow-mindedly moralistic
semaphore:1: an apparatus for visual signaling (as by the position of one or more movable arms)
semblance: outward and often specious appearance or show : form
seminal: of, relating to, or consisting of seed or semen
simpleton: a person lacking in common sense
soiree: a party or reception held in the evening
solecism: an ungrammatical combination of words in a sentence; also : a minor blunder in speech
solemnity: formal or ceremonious observance of an occasion or event
solidarity: unity (as of a group or class) that produces or is based on community of interests, objectives, and standards
solipsism: a theory holding that the self can know nothing but its own modifications and that the self is the only existent thing; also : extreme egocentrism
somatic: of, relating to, or affecting the body especially as distinguished from the germplasm
sparing: marked by or practicing careful restraint (as in the use of resources)
specious: having a false look of truth or genuineness : sophistic
stardom: the status or position of a star
stuporous: marked or affected by or as if by stupor
sublime:1: to cause to pass directly from the solid to the vapor state and condense back to solid form
subtend: to be opposite to and extend from one side to the other of
succinct: marked by compact precise expression without wasted words
supple:1: compliant often to the point of obsequiousness
sycophancy: obsequious flattery; also : the character or behavior of a sycophant
tantamount: equivalent in value, significance, or effect
temerity: unreasonable or foolhardy contempt of danger or opposition : rashness, recklessness
temperance: moderation in action, thought, or feeling : restraint
tenuous: having little substance or strength : flimsy, weak
threadbare: having the nap worn off so that the thread shows : shabby
tide:1: the alternate rising and falling of the surface of the ocean and of water bodies (such as gulfs and bays) connected with the ocean that occurs usually twice a day and is the result of differing gravitational forces exerted at different parts of the earth by another body (such as the moon or sun)
transgression: an act, process, or instance of transgressing: such as
transgress: to violate a command or law : sin
travail:1: work especially of a painful or laborious nature : toil
trifling: lacking in significance or solid worth: such as
triptych: a picture (such as an altarpiece) or carving in three panels side by side
trite: hackneyed or boring from much use : not fresh or original
troglodyte: a member of any of various peoples (as in antiquity) who lived or were reputed to live chiefly in caves
trope: a word or expression used in a figurative sense : figure of speech
truancy: an act or instance of playing truant : the state of being truant
tumult: disorderly agitation or milling about of a crowd usually with uproar and confusion of voices : commotion
turgid: excessively embellished in style or language : bombastic, pompous
twinge:1: a sudden sharp stab of pain
unperturbed: not worried, upset, or disquieted : not perturbed
unrequited: not requited : not reciprocated or returned in kind
unsparing: not merciful or forbearing : hard, ruthless
uproot: to remove as if by pulling up
usurp: to seize and hold (office, place, functions, powers, etc.) in possession by force or without right
usurper: one who usurps something: such as
vacillate: to waver in mind, will, or feeling : hesitate in choice of opinions or courses
venerate: to regard with reverential respect or with admiring deference
veracity: conformity with truth or fact : accuracy
vigil: the act of keeping awake at times when sleep is customary; also : a period of wakefulness
vindicate: to free from allegation or blame
virile: having traditionally masculine traits especially to a marked degree
virility: the quality or state of being virile:
visceral: felt in or as if in the internal organs of the body : deep
volition: the power of choosing or determining : will
whimsical: resulting from or characterized by whim or caprice; especially : lightly fanciful
